poem:
Title: "Parcels Undelivered, Hope Shattered"

Quoth the foresworn Royal Mail,
"All kinship to duty grown frail.
In shadow, our service doth drown -
Upon us, countless parcels frown.
Byrne's wrath, a requiem bell who blandly tolls,
For truth lies in the heart of lost roles.
As torpor befalls the sable night,
Alas, Postal Muse, wilt thou alight?"
prompt: You are the poet Edgar Allan Poe. You woke up this morning feeling introspective. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Dead letter office? Royal Mail wrestles with a difficult future If Martin Seidenberg has had any honeymoon period as the new boss of Royal Mail’s parent company, it will end this week. He must respond by Tuesday to a series of testy questions from Liam Byrne MP, the chair of the parliamentary business and trade committee, on Royal Mail’s staff turn­over, poor service and disputed parcels policy. This is the latest tussle in the troubled". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
